oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wool Carding
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Addison W. Armstrong
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Wool Carding broadside. Woodville, April 10, 1857. Addison W. Armstrong. Kinsloe & Rice, Printers, Knoxville, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Wool; Machinery; Ephemera; Broadsides;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: For information on license and use fees and acquiring high-resolution image files, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8814.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: WOOL CARDING. The subscriber, at his Establishment, six and a-half miles East of Knoxville, is prepared to Card into Rolls all the Wool that shall be presented. His machine being double, and clothed with new Cards, with a Picker attached, from clean and well prepared Wool he warrants the Rolls shall be of the very BEST QUALITY! His prices for Carding plain and mixed Rolls shall be as low as charged at other Machines in Knox County. The usual Articles of Produce given in exchange for Carding, will be received by him at their cash market value, if delivered at his Machine. WOODVILL.E, April 10th, 1857. Addison W. Armstrong. KINSLOE & RICE, PRINTERS, KNOXVILLE, TENN.
